ng template.text: already being used under the hood for common directives such as *ngIf, *ngFor and *ngSwitch

ng container.text: you cannot have 2 structural directives on the same node, but ideally you don't want to create an unnecessary extra div - ng-container fixes this issue
ng container.code:
<div *ngIf="lessons">
    <div class="lesson" *ngFor="let lesson of lessons">...
// can be done as:

<ng-container *ngIf="lessons">
    <div class="lesson" *ngFor="let lesson of lessons">

 Tmux helps with this - instead of window -E tab - terminal - shell it does window - tab - terminal -E shell.
 More accurately we have something more like window - tab - terminal shell -E tmux session -E tmux window -E tmux pane - tmux shell. npm link.step1: go into your (generated) dist folder (I always copy my package.json into my dist folder so this might be necessary)
npm link.step3: go into the project that's using your project
npm link.step4: npm link <npm dependency name from package.json>
npm link.step5: for bonus points build this link command into your npm scripts so you don't have to bother with a readme and add a npm watch in to rebuild as soon as your dependency updates
npm link.note: it isn't possible to chain together modules using npm link as it doesn't move your linked node_modules into your generated node_modules - you can work around this by also running npm link in your dist folder everytime you generate it

managing multiple accounts on one machin.prerequisite: we're going to make use of conditional includes in your .gitconfig (introduced with git v2.13) so ensure that your different projects share a unique parent folder

step_2.code: ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -C "<the email address used by your first github repo>"

managing multiple accounts on one machin.step_5: run ls to see the 2 files generated - the .pub contains the public key that can go on github; the other file contains your private key
managing multiple accounts on one machin.step_6: copy the public key, login to your github then go to settings > SSH and GPG keys > new SSH key
managing multiple accounts on one machin.step_7: paste the key in and save
managing multiple accounts on one machin.step_8: repeat steps 1-7 but with the email address used by your next github repo(s) - name it something appropriate eg rsa_work

step_10.code:
Host github.com
   HostName github.com
   User git
   IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa_personal
Host github.com-work
   HostName github.com
   User git
   IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa_work

managing multiple accounts on one machin.step_14: call ssh-add passing the new paths eg ssh-add id_rsa_personal, ssh-add id_rsa_work
managing multiple accounts on one machin.step_15: ssh-add -l - confirm that the keys have been added
managing multiple accounts on one machin.step_17: done! now whenever your within your contextual folder it will use the appropriate credentials - please remember to update the github url to whatever you've got in your .ssh/config (in my case my personal stuff stays unmodified and my work I change ot github.com-work). Also remember the condition includes will only work in git initialised repos
